clarifications: What is the expected URL for accessing this "Hello, World!" page?
Are there any specific styling or branding requirements for the HTML page beyond plain text?
What web server technology (e.g., Apache, Nginx, Node.js, Python SimpleHTTPServer) is preferred, if any?
Should the 'Hello, World!' message be a static file or dynamically generated?
definition_of_done: The text "Hello, World!" is visibly displayed in a standard web browser (e.g., Chrome, Firefox, Edge).
The content is delivered as valid HTML.
The page loads without any console errors or HTTP error codes (e.g., 404, 500).
description: The system shall display the text "Hello, World!" as a basic HTML page when accessed via a web browser.

stories.description: As a user, I want to see a "Hello, World!" message displayed in my web browser when I visit the application's root URL so that I can confirm the basic web server functionality is working.

tasks.description: Set up a minimal web server environment capable of serving static HTML files.

subtasks.description: Implement the necessary configuration or code to start a basic web server.
Document the steps and dependencies required to set up and run the web server.

tasks.description: Create an HTML file named 'index.html' containing the "Hello, World!" message.

subtasks.description: Implement the HTML structure with a body containing the text "Hello, World!".
Document the content and expected location of the 'index.html' file within the project structure.

tasks.description: Configure the web server to serve the 'index.html' file as the default page for the root URL.

subtasks.description: Implement the server configuration to map the root URL to 'index.html'.
Document the web server configuration changes or code required to serve the HTML file correctly.

clarifications: What are the exact hexadecimal color codes (or RGB values) for "blueish dark gray" and "light blueish gray"?
How should these styles be applied (e.g., inline CSS, internal CSS block in <head>, external CSS file)?
Are there any specific fonts or font sizes to consider in addition to colors?
definition_of_done: The "Hello, World!" text is rendered with the specified "blueish dark gray" color.
The background of the HTML page is rendered with the specified "light blueish gray" color.
The applied styles are consistent across modern web browsers (e.g., Chrome, Firefox, Edge).
description: The system shall apply specific styling to the "Hello, World!" page, including a "blueish dark gray" text color and a "light blueish gray" background color.

stories.description: As a user, I want the 'Hello, World!' text to be 'blueish dark gray' and the page background to be 'light blueish gray' so that the application meets the specified visual design requirements.

tasks.description: Define and apply the text color for the 'Hello, World!' message.

subtasks.description: Implement the CSS rule to set the color of the 'Hello, World!' text to 'blueish dark gray'.
Document the specific color code used for the text and where the CSS rule is applied.

tasks.description: Define and apply the background color for the HTML page.

subtasks.description: Implement the CSS rule to set the background color of the HTML body or relevant container to 'light blueish gray'.
Document the specific color code used for the background and where the CSS rule is applied.

tasks.description: Integrate the new styling rules into the 'index.html' file.

subtasks.description: Implement the chosen method for integrating CSS (e.g., adding a <style> block to the HTML <head> or creating/linking an external CSS file).
Document the integration method used for the CSS and any new files or file structure changes.

clarifications: What specific element should the blur effect be applied to (e.g., the 'Hello, World!' text itself, the entire page content, a specific container)?
What is the desired intensity of the blur (e.g., in pixels, like `filter: blur(5px)`)?
Should the blur effect be static, or should there be an option for a user to toggle it on/off?
Are there any performance considerations for older browsers or devices regarding the blur effect?
definition_of_done: The specified element on the web page appears visibly blurred in a standard web browser (e.g., Chrome, Firefox, Edge).
The blur effect is applied using standard CSS properties (e.g., `filter: blur()`).
The blur effect is consistent across common modern web browsers and does not significantly impact page load time or rendering performance.
description: The system shall apply a blur effect to a designated element on the "Hello, World!" page.

stories.description: As a user, I want a specific element on the 'Hello, World!' page to display with a blur effect so that the page incorporates the desired visual enhancement.

tasks.description: Identify the target element for the blur effect and determine the appropriate CSS property.

subtasks.description: Implement a small proof-of-concept demonstrating `filter: blur()` or an alternative CSS property on a test element.
Document the chosen CSS property (`filter: blur()`) and its general browser compatibility.

tasks.description: Apply the blur effect to the designated element on the 'Hello, World!' page.

subtasks.description: Implement the CSS rule to apply the `filter: blur()` to the chosen element (e.g., the element containing 'Hello, World!' text).
Document the CSS selector used for the target element and the specific blur intensity value applied.

tasks.description: Verify the blur effect's rendering and performance across target web browsers.

subtasks.description: Conduct cross-browser testing to ensure the blur effect renders consistently and doesn't cause performance issues.
Document the results of browser compatibility testing, noting any discrepancies or necessary workarounds.
